node.title: Waitangi Day commemorations go online
node.description: Today's Waitangi Day commemorations were like never before with the Waitangi Treaty Grounds closed due to Covid-19 and ceremonies going online.

node.title: The first medals are awarded in Beijing as competition enters full swing.
node.description: The first full day of events brought an upset. Karen Chen is set to skate for the United States and Jamie Anderson aims for her third straight gold medal in snowboarding.

node.title: NZ to attend UN environment assembly session
node.description: New Zealand will be taking part in commemorating 50 years of the United Nations Environment Programme this year, with a delegation possibly travelling to Kenya for the event.

node.title: Five-year-old dies after four days trapped inside well in Morocco
node.description: A five-year-old Moroccan boy who was trapped in a well for four days has died, despite painstaking efforts to rescue him.

node.title: Police seek dangerous fugitive who fled after funeral
node.description: Police are appealing for sightings of a dangerous prisoner who failed to return to jail after he was granted permission to attend a funeral.

node.title: U.N. report says North Korea funding nuclear program with cyberattack earnings
node.description: The report on North Korea's nuclear advancements comes at a time when tensions among Security Council members are running high.

node.title: Families, investigators remain haunted by unsolved Texas yogurt shop murders
node.description: Could new information lead to answers in the brutal murder of four teenage girls in Austin, Texas, 30 years ago?

node.title: Are 2 never-identified customers key to solving yogurt shop murders?
node.description: Two men were seen in a Texas yogurt shop just before four teenage girls were killed there in 1991, and some wonder whether identifying them will lead to answers in the unsolved case.

node.title: Australia's Tess Coady claims Winter Olympic bronze medal in slopestyle snowboarding
node.description: Australia has its first medal of the Beijing Winter Olympics, with Tess Coady claimingÂ bronze in the women's slopestyle snowboarding final.

node.title: Queen Elizabeth quietly marks 70 years on the British throne
node.description: Queen Elizabeth marks 70 years on the British throne on Sunday, a milestone never reached by any of her predecessors over the past 1000 years.

node.title: Floating carpet of dead fish found off French coast
node.description: Dutch-owned trawler FV Margiris, the world's second-biggest fishing vessel, shed more than 100,000 dead fish into the Atlantic Ocean off France.

node.title: Beijing Winter Olympics: Sadowski-Synnott eases into finals
node.description: New Zealand's Zoi Sadowski-Synnott has cruised into the finals of the women's snowboard slopestyle qualifiers at the Beijing Olympics.

node.title: Skiers prepare to hurtle down an unfamiliar and treacherous course.
node.description: The pandemic has kept the new racecourse outside Beijing from hosting preparatory events over the past two years.

node.title: Hundreds gather in Minneapolis to demand justice for Amir Locke
node.description: Police fatally shot Locke early Wednesday morning while executing a search warrant.

node.title: West Coast turns to recovery and repairs after heavy rains
node.description: The clean up begins today in parts of the West Coast, after hundreds of people were evacuated on Friday night over fears of flooding.

node.title: Tertiary Education Union concerned funding changes will 'rob Peter to pay Paul'
node.description: The Tertiary Education Union is worried small polytechnics will not survive a major overhaul of education funding, despite the viability of small polytechnics being a goal of the changes.

node.title: Slips and surface flooding warnings for Taranaki
node.description: Heavy rain is expected to cause slips and flooding in Taranaki today, on the back of 24 hours of deluges.

node.title: International Space Station to crash down to Earth in 2031
node.description: When the International Space Station wears out, it is likely to be dumped in an uninhabited area of the Pacific Ocean, off the coast of New Zealand.

node.title: Olympics isolation room upgrade requested
node.description: Olympic champion's isolation room at the Beijing Winter Games is "unacceptable", Germany's team chief says.

node.title: NFL commissioner calls league's record of hiring minority coaches "unacceptable"
node.description: Goodell also announced an independent investigation into claims of tanking brought up in former Dolphins coach Brian Flores' lawsuit against the league.

node.title: Picasso's anti-war tapestry Guernica returns to the U.N.
node.description: A Rockefeller family member commissioned the Guernica tapestry after Picasso refused to sell them the original painting, according to a historian.

node.title: Queen Elizabeth backs plan to one day call Prince Charles' wife Queen Camilla
node.description: Queen Elizabeth II offers her support to have the Duchess of Cornwall become Queen Camilla

node.title: Queen Elizabeth says she wants Camilla to be named Queen Consort when Charles becomes king
node.description: When Prince Charles and Camilla married in 2005, Clarence House said Camilla's title would be "Princess Consort" when Charles became king.

node.title: Turkish President Erdogan tests positive for COVID-19
node.description: Turkey has seen record levels of COVID-19 cases in recent days, with 111,157 cases reported by the Health Ministry on Friday.

node.title: A D.C. bar shut down after defying vaccination requirements has a new life as a conservative rallying point.
node.description: Senator Rand Paul and other Republicans are lionizing The Big Board, a family-owned bar a mile from the U.S. Capitol.

node.title: MIQ soon to be a thing of the past but Covid wounds run deep
node.description: Power Play - The festering political boil MIQ has been lanced but despite the delight, the social and economic wounds inflicted by Covid-19 will take longer to heal, writes Jane Patterson.

node.title: One dead and four injured after Auckland crash
node.description: One person has died at the scene of a crash in Auckland last night, and four other people have been left injured.

node.title: Mount Everest's highest glacier melting fast, study says
node.description: Climate change is causing the highest glacier on Mount Everest to melt at a rapid pace, a new study has found.

node.title: Covid-19 cover needed for school support staff - Greens
node.description: The Green Party wants the government to cover extra sick days for school support staff through the pandemic.

node.title: Covid-19 record numbers: 'I urge people not to panic, but to plan' - Hipkins
node.description: The Covid-19 Response Minister says there is no need to panic as the country records its largest daily total of new communty cases since the pandemic began.
